description: As of the evening of  March 31, Montenegro imposed a curfew: All individuals are prohibited from leaving their residence between 19:00 and 05:00 on weekdays, and between 13:00 on Saturday and 05:00 on Monday. Exemptions will be made for those providing essential public services. Additionally, authorities issued a ban on gatherings in residential buildings of persons who are not members of the same household. All sports and recreational activities in public spaces have also been barred.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
As of the evening of March 31, Montenegro imposed a curfew: All individuals are prohibited from leaving their residence between 19:00 and 05:00 on weekdays, and between 13:00 on Saturday and 05:00 on Monday. Exemptions will be made for those providing essential public services. Additionally, authorities issued a ban on gatherings in residential buildings of persons who are not members of the same household. All sports and recreational activities in public spaces have also been barred.

UPDATE: As of 21 April these measures were relaxed and thus the original curfew was ended.

description: Montenegrin authorities announced on Tuesday, April 21, that the current nationwide curfew would be shortened as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) lockdown measures begin to ease following a decrease in confirmed cases. The new curfew is now in effect between the hours of 23:00 and 05:00 (local time) on weekdays.

Montenegrin authorities announced on Tuesday, April 21, that the current nationwide curfew would be shortened as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) curfew measures begin to ease following a decrease in confirmed cases. The new curfew is now in effect between the hours of 23:00 and 05:00 (local time) on weekdays. 

UPDATE: Montenegrin authorities announced on Friday, May 15, that some coronavirus disease (COVID-19) restrictions would be lifted, including previous overnight movement bans.

On April 28th Montenegro Airlines have prolonged the ban on commercial air traffic from Montenegro, as well as the restriction from other countries for travel until May 15th 2020. including that date.

On March 16th, Montenegro's state airline has suspended all flights until 22 April following government halt. All international bus and railway services have also been suspended. There is also an entry ban for cruisers and yachts to ports: Bar, Budva, Kotor, Kumbor Port – Portonovi, Tivat (Gat I and Gat II) and Zelenika, until 2 April.
On May 11, 2020 the National Coordination Body for Communicable Diseases in Montenegro  has decided to l allow personal and public transportation of passengers – but within the regions.

Beginning March 22, Montenegro's government is publishing lists containing the personal data of self-quarantined citizens who are thought to have come into contact with the potentially deadly COVID-19 coronavirus.

Montenegro, March 13 -  Government of Montenegro instructed the Office for the Property Administration, as well as the competent services of local self-government units, to procure additional quantities of hygiene products, products for hand disinfection, as well as products for disinfection of working spaces and working equipment for the needs of state bodies, state administration bodies, administrative bodies and bodies of local government. Procurement should be performed in accordance with the recommendations of the Institute of Public Health of Montenegro.

Procurement should be performed in accordance with the recommendations of the Institute of Public Health of Montenegro.

description: Beginning March 13, Montenegro's government is publishing lists containing the personal data of self-quarantined citizens who are thought to have come into contact with the potentially deadly COVID-19 coronavirus.

On March 13, Montenegro announced additional measures to tackle the outbreak. One of them is the publishing, on the government website, of personal data, including names, of people who are self-quarantined after  possible infection from the virus.

Beginning March 13, Montenegro's government is publishing lists containing the personal data of self-quarantined citizens who are thought to have come into contact with the potentially deadly COVID-19 coronavirus. As of April 25, Montenegro's government has stopped publishing this list containing personal data of self-isolating persons.

Montenegro, from March 15, is enforcing compulsory quarantine for all Montenegrin citizens, as well as for foreigners who have permanent or temporary residence in Montenegro, who come from abroad, for a period of 14 days based on the decision of the health and sanitary inspection.

Montenegro is enforcing on businesses, as of March 15, the obligation of responsible persons in trade establishments to provide or mark a distance, of at least two meters between persons located in front of retail outlets, at cash registers and sectors where goods are served by employees in the outlet.

The Montenegrin Ministry of Health, as of March 15, adopted temporary measures to prevent the introduction into the country, suppress and prevent the transmission of new coronavirus. This resulted in the closure of: catering services in hotels (excepting registered guests), disco clubs/ bars and nightclubs/ bars, catering establishments (cafes, pubs, cafeterias, restaurants and bars, excepting catering establishments that deliver food and allow food and meals to be taken over, with a ban on the stay of guests in the facilities themselves), ban on providing shopping and catering services in shopping malls ,children's playrooms, fitness centres, casinos/ betting shops and gambling outlets.

Montenegrin businesses, from March 15, must limit the number of customers, in relation to the area of the retail outlet, so that only one consumer can be located in ten square meters of the surface of the outlet. Regardless of the surface, no more than 50 consumers can reside in a retail outlet at a time. Exceptionally for markets and bazaars, the number of customers who can be in the facility simultaneously limits up to 100 consumers.

Montenegro, as of March 15, makes the responsible persons in the trade establishments obligated to indicate at the entrance to the sales facility the notification of the maximum number of persons, who can be in the same facility at the same time and to organise the implementation of this measure.

On March 17, Montenegro's Ministry of Health restricted/regulated the following businesses: hair and beauty salons closed, and the operation of indoor and outdoor sports and recreational facilities and swimming pools was prohibited.

On March 17, Montenegro's Ministry of Health restricted/regulated the following businesses: hair and beauty salons closed, and the operation of indoor and outdoor sports and recreational facilities and swimming pools was prohibited.

On March 18, Montenegro banned the operation of commercial facilities, except pharmacies and facilities where food, beverages, hygiene products, motor fuels, construction products, plant protection products and planting products, animal nutrition and treatment products are traded.

Montenegro's National Coordination Body allows retail outlets to be opened until 6 p.m. on April 18 (Holy Saturday). retail outlets refers to: pharmacies, food, beverage and hygiene facilities, specialized facilities for the sale of baby equipment, construction products, plant protection products and planting products, animal nutrition and treatment products, agricultural machinery and funeral equipment.
Montenegro is allowing retail outlets/consumer goods stores to work from 7am to 10pm on working days and Saturdays starting April 21.

Montenegro has new measures regarding businesses, which enter into force on the day of publication, and apply from May 4: the employer is obliged to provide the employees with a protective mask and disinfectant while working in the facilities, premises and vehicles.

Montenegro has new measures regarding businesses, which enter into force on the day of publication, and apply from May 4: the employer is obliged to provide the employees with a protective mask and disinfectant while working in the facilities, premises and vehicles.
Montenegro's National Coordination Body for Communicable Diseases from May 15, has reopened catering facilities with conditions.
Montenegro's National Coordination Body agrees to ease measures: shopping malls reopen from May 15.
Montenegro's National Coordination Body for Communicable Diseases from May 15, has reopened catering facilities with conditions.

Montenegro from July 26 enters into force that all catering facilities in Montenegro can work from 6:00 a.m. to 12 a.m. The decision refers to restaurants, cafes, cafeterias, hotel restaurants and similar catering facilities, as well as the provision of catering services at beaches and bathing areas.

The National Coordination Body for Communicable Diseases decided today, at the suggestion of the Public Health Institute of Montenegro, to allow catering facilities to work from 6:00 a.m. until 1:00 a.m.

On March 18th, Montenegro's Ministry of Health announced, as part of broader measures, the suspension of public transport of passengers (suburban and urban) by bus and van
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 21, Montenegro announced it was banning gatherings for weddings, and only allowing funerals with immediate family members.

On March 21, Montenegro announced it was banning gatherings for weddings, and only allowing funerals with immediate family members.

From June 1, as part of the re-opening program, up to 200 people can attend all types of gatherings, both outdoors and indoors, in public places, including wedding festivities and funerals.

On May 4, 2020 the government in Montenegro announced that  “A legal person will have to pay a fine ranging from €2.000 to €20.000 for failing to ensure practicing of physical distance measures among people in their facilities and protective equipment – face masks – for employees providing trade services, hospitality services, those working in hairdresser and beauty salons."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside public or commercial building
